<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_:
```c
int
MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (const char *const str1,
                           const char *const str2,
                           size_t maxlen)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < maxlen; ++i)
  {
    const char c1 = str1[i];
    const char c2 = str2[i];
    if (0 == c2)
      return 0 == c1;
    if (charsequalcaseless (c1, c2))
      continue;
    else
      return 0;
  }
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
const char c1 = str1[i];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Violation: if str1 points to a buffer smaller than maxlen (for example a 2-byte buffer containing {'A','B'} with no further storage) and str2 is at least maxlen bytes long with matching leading bytes, the loop will reach i==2 and execute str1[2] which is beyond the bounds of the object. Because the code reads str1[i] unconditionally before any check on str2 or bounds, this can produce an out-of-bounds access, violating MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
